none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from Irene Gartner, July 5, 1883
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from Irene Gartner, July 5, 1883
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 14 Louis L. McInnis Papers

en: Personal letter from Irene Gartner to Professor Louis L. McInnis dated July 5, 1883, from Huntsville, Texas, requesting assistance with settling a bill for Miss Hall and acknowledging McInnis's help with various financial matters. The letter reveals Gartner's health struggles with recurring chills and expresses gratitude for McInnis's support in managing her affairs, while inquiring about his summer plans and extending family regards.

body.value:
[Margin: Mrs Gartner
rc / July 8 / 83
ansd
July 22 1884]

[Stamp: Postmark HUNTSVILLE TEX JUL 8]
[Stamp: US Postage Three Cents]

Prof. L. L. McInnis
College Station
Texas. —

It appears that the goal is to fully transcribe the contents. Therefore I will include all of the characters in the image, even if some of them are hard to read. Here's my thought process as I go through this. I can see the main address is for "Prof. L. L. McInnis, College Station, Texas." The postmark says "HUNTSVILLE JUL 8 TEX." I also see a stamp that reads "US Postage, 3 Cents." I can make out a green color and a profile of Washington on the stamp. Then, there's some text written vertically on the left side of the envelope. I'll tackle this marginalia first. It seems to read "Mrs Gartner" in red pencil at the top. The rest of the text is in black ink. It looks like "rc / July 8 / 83," then "ansd," and finally "July 22 1884." Hmm, that date "July 22 1884." Why is that year different? I'm going to transcribe exactly what I see. Okay, let's look at the letters. I think this first section is pretty clear. I can clearly read "rc / July 8 / 83". The last digit in the two dates is critical. Is that a '3' or a '4'? Okay, focusing really hard, it looks like "3" and "4." Okay, let's start writing it out. I think I'll use a `p` tag with line breaks inside. Here is the transcription:

[Margin: Mrs Gartner
rc / July 8 / 83
ansd
July 22 1884]

[Stamp: Postmark HUNTSVILLE TEX JUL 8]
[Stamp: 3 cents US Postage]

Prof. L. L. McInnis
College Station
Texas. —

[Header]

Huntsville Tex
July 5th 1883.

Prof. L. L. McInnis;
Dear Sir:

Your letter with
enclosed voucher, I received yesterday.
Please settle the Miss Hall bill
for me; I will be so glad when
it is paid. — It was quite a
surpise to me, that Mr Gardner
was allowed $ 38 for improvements
I did not expect it at all. ——
I thank you very, very much
Mr McInnis, for the kind
interest you take in my affairs.
We all hope to see you this summer.
I am again suffering with chills,
+ of course feel lowspirited + discouraged;
I had a very hard one yesterday, it seems
impossible for me, to get well.
Are you going North this Summer?
I hope you will have a pleasant
vacation, + get thoroughly rested.
Mother + Sister join me in kind
wishes

[Signature]

Sincerely,
Irene Gardner.
